Bayesian inference in

Marie-Hélène Burle

February 25, 2025


On probabilities

Two interpretations of probabilities


Frequentist

Bayesian

Frequentist

Frequentist approach to probabilities: assigns probabilities to the long-run frequency of events

For events for which there is no long-run, you imagine alternative realities and consider the frequency of occurrences in all those realities

The frequentist approach is computationally simpler and faster and returns summary statistics

Bayesian

Bayesian approach: assigns probabilities to our beliefs about an event

Based on Bayes’ theorem of conditional probabilities which allows to calculate the probability of a cause given its effect:

\[ P(A \vert X) = \frac{P(X \vert A) P(A)}{P(X)} \]

where:

  • \(P(A)\) is the prior probability of \(A\)—our belief about event \(A\)
  • \(P(X)\) is the marginal probability of event \(X\) (some observed data)
  • \(P(X \vert A)\) is the likelihood or conditional probability of observing \(X\) given \(A\)
  • \(P(A \vert X)\) is the posterior probability—our updated belief about \(A\) given the data

Which approach to choose?

Bayesian statistics:

  • is more intuitive to the way we think about the world (easier to interpret)
  • allows for the incorporation of prior information and diverse data
  • is more informative as it provides a measure of uncertainty (returns probabilities)
  • is extremely valuable when there is little data (the inference is unstable and frequentist estimates have large variance and confidence intervals)

But beyond extremely simple examples, Bayesian inference is mathematically arduous

It is also much more computationally heavy and only became possible to apply widely with the advent of powerful computers and new algorithms such as Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)

Bayesian computing

Algorithms

Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)

Probabilistic Programming Language

Since the Bayesian approach is computationally intensive, the choice of framework, language, and compiler is important

Probabilistic programming language (PPL), explained simply in this (now outdated) blog post, are xxx

First PPLs

Rely on Gibbs sampling

  • WinBUGS replaced by OpenBUGS, written in Component Pascal

  • later JAGS, written in C++

Stan

Stan, see also website and paper, is a domain-specific language

You write a Stan script that you can then call from R, Python, or the shell via RStan, PyStan, etc.

Also used as the backend for brms in R which doesn’t require learning Stan but only works for simple models

Relies on No-U-Turn sampler (NUTS), a variant of Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC)—see HMC paper

Superior to Gibbs sampler ➔ made Stan a very popular PPL for years

HMC and variants require burdensome calculations of derivatives

Stan solved that by creating its own reverse-mode automatic differentiation engine

PPLs based on deep learning frameworks

Since HMC and NUTS require autodiff, many software have emerged in recent years, following the explosion of deep learning

(The Stan developers wrote their own autodiff system)

Examples:

  • Pyro based on PyTorch
  • Edward, then Edward2 as well as TensorFlow Probability based on TensorFlow

Enters JAX


Had JAX existed when we started coding Stan in 2011, we would’ve used that rather than rolling our own autodiff system.

Bob Carpenter, one of Stan’s creators, in a recent blog post

What is JAX?

JAX is a library for Python that:

  • makes use of the extremely performant XLA compiler
  • runs on accelerators (GPUs/TPUs)
  • provides automatic differentiation
  • uses just-in-time compilation
  • allows batching and parallelization

⇒ perfect tool for Bayesian statistics


See our introductory JAX course and webinar for more details

JAX use cases

New backends using JAX

Edward2 and TensorFlow Probability can now use JAX as a backend

PyMC

Library for Python

PyMC is a PPL based on PyTensor—fork of aesara, itself a fork of Theano

It relies on building a static graph

pymc-extras is a testing ground for novel algorithms, distributions, and methods

NumPyro

Library for Python

NumPyro based on Pyro but uses NumPy and JAX

Blackjax

Not a PPL but a library of MCMC samplers for Python

Can be used directly if you want to define your own log-probability density functions or can be used with several PPLs (make sure to translate the model into a log-probability function)

Also provides building blocks for experimentation with new algorithms

Blackjax

Example Blackjax sampler: HMC

Example Blackjax sampler: NUTS

Which tool to choose?

All these tools are in active development (JAX was released and started shaking the field in 2018). Things are fast evolving. Reading blogs of main developers, posts on Hacker News, discourse forums, etc. helps keeping on eye on the evolutions in the field

This recent conversation between Bob Carpenter (Stan core developer) and Ricardo Vieira (PyMC core developer) in the PyMC discourse forum is interesting

A lot of it also comes down to user preferences

Resources

How to get started with Bayesian computing?

The book Probabilistic Programming & Bayesian Methods for Hackers by Cameron Davidson-Pilon provides a code-based (using PyMC) and math-free introduction to Bayesian methods for the real beginner

Several resources on the PyMC website

NumPyro tutorials

More advanced: tutorials from Blackjax Sampling Book Project

How to transition from Stan to a JAX-based PPL?

The code to the classic Bayesian textbook Statistical Rethinking by Richard McElreath got translated by various people to modern JAX-based PPLs:
